results.abstract: Floyd D Hall, former airline pilot who rose to become chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines in the mid-1960s, dies at age 96. Photo (M)

headline.main: Floyd D. Hall, 96, Headed Eastern Airlines

results.snippet: Floyd D. Hall, a former airline pilot who rose to chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines in the mid-1960s but who was unable to stem the financial difficulties that eventually led to the company's demise, died on April 26 at a nursing home...
results.lead_paragraph: Floyd D. Hall, a former airline pilot who rose to chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines in the mid-1960s but who was unable to stem the financial difficulties that eventually led to the company's demise, died on April 26 at a nursing home in Woodstock, Vt. He was 96. His daughter, Nancy Morton, confirmed his death.

headline.main: What's On Today

results.snippet: 8:30 P.M. (13) FAUST Des McAnuff, the artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, whose revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' is now on Broadway, makes his Metropolitan Opera debut with Gounod's ''Faust,'' updated to the 20th century....
results.lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (13) FAUST Des McAnuff, the artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, whose revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' is now on Broadway, makes his Metropolitan Opera debut with Gounod's ''Faust,'' updated to the 20th century. Jonas Kaufmann stars as a nuclear scientist, despairing of the effects of his life's work, who makes a contract with the Devil. Marina Poplavskaya, above with Mr. Kaufmann, is Marguerite, Faust's love interest and eventual victim, and René Pape reprises his role as Méphistophélès. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducted this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation, which was shown live in movie theaters on Dec. 10. ''It is better if a production does not look too deeply for elements of existential despair that are simply not in the piece, and that seems the problem with the new 'Faust,' '' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, adding that this co-production with the English National Opera, ''though rich with ideas and theatrically daring, is finally rather clinical and oppressive.'' 7:45 A.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut of Sarah Polley, who earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

results.abstract: Some additional edited excerpts from the interview.

headline.main: More Quality Family Time With the Wainwrights and Roches

results.snippet: Some additional edited excerpts from the interview.
results.lead_paragraph: The Scene:The family showed up at Dixon Place, the cozy, pretty performance space on the Lower East Side. Cameras, both still and video, had already been set up and there was a circle of chairs waiting, but they made sure they had all hugged and welcomed each other before taking a seat. There was very little tension and subtext as they settled in, much more of it when the recorder came on, and then none of it once they had finished. The Wainwrights and Roches know how to reveal just enough conflict to make for an interesting interview, but nothing that creates lasting grudges. When the group interview was done, three generations, siblings and half-siblings, grandpa and shy grandchild, all began weighing in on where the gigantic crew might eat. This is a family that likes and loves each other very much, even if they don't always pretend to get along. Below are some additional edited excerpts from the interview.

headline.main: Testing Private Ship to the Space Station, and Wine, Too

results.snippet: In space, how quickly does grape juice turn to wine?     Two California high school students hope to find out soon. Their experiment is one of 11 aboard a rocket scheduled to blast off early Saturday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., to the International...
results.lead_paragraph: In space, how quickly does grape juice turn to wine? Two California high school students hope to find out soon. Their experiment is one of 11 aboard a rocket scheduled to blast off early Saturday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., to the International Space Station. ''We think it's going to ferment faster,'' said Max Holden, a ninth grader at Chaminade College Preparatory in West Hills, Calif.

results.abstract: Bob Dylan was praised by President Obama and presented with a Medal of Freedom at the White House on Tuesday, alongside other honorees who included Toni Morrison, Madeleine K. Albright, John Paul Stevens, John Glenn and Shimon Peres.

headline.main: Bob Dylan Among Recipients of Presidential Medal of Freedom

results.snippet: Bob Dylan was praised by President Obama and presented with a Medal of Freedom at the White House on Tuesday, alongside other honorees who included Toni Morrison, Madeleine K. Albright, John Paul Stevens, John Glenn and Shimon Peres.
results.lead_paragraph: It would be an overstatement to say that the whole wide world was watching when Bob Dylan's ship came in, but surely his fans pinched themselves and squealed and knew that it was for real when he was awarded a Presidential Medal of Freedom on Tuesday afternoon. Mr. Dylan, 71, whose career of more than 50 years stretches from early folk songs like "The Times They Are A-Changin'" and "When the Ship Comes In" to the recondite rock of recent albums like "Modern Times" and "Together Through Life," was presented with the medal at a ceremony in the White House, where President Obama said of him, "There is not a bigger giant in the history of American music." Mr. Obama also praised Mr. Dylan's voice for its "weight" and "unique gravelly power" that redefined "not just what music sounded like but the message it carried and how it made people feel."

results.abstract: Photos of Pres Obama awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to recipients of the nation's highest civilian honor. Photos (M)6

headline.main: AN HONOR FROM THE PRESIDENT

results.snippet: President Obama, who recalled listening in college days as Bob Dylan's ''gravelly'' voice redefined ''not just what music sounded like but the message it carried,'' awards him the Presidential Medal of Freedom at a ceremony on Tuesday. ''This is a...
results.lead_paragraph: President Obama, who recalled listening in college days as Bob Dylan's ''gravelly'' voice redefined ''not just what music sounded like but the message it carried,'' awards him the Presidential Medal of Freedom at a ceremony on Tuesday. ''This is a packed house,'' Mr. Obama remarked, ''which is a testament to how cool this group is.'' The other recipients of the nation's highest civilian honor were former secretary of state Madeleine Albright; John Doar, assistant attorney general of the civil rights era; William Foege, a physician who worked to eradicate smallpox; John Glenn, astronaut and senator; Dolores Huerta, a founder of the farm workers union; the writer Toni Morrison; the Israeli leader Shimon Peres; John Paul Stevens, retired Justice of the Supreme Court; Pat Summitt, the top college women's basketball coach who now speaks on Alzheimer's disease; and, all posthumously, Gordon Hirabayashi, who challenged the wartime internment of Japanese Americans; Jan Karski, a member of the Polish underground who exposed Nazi atrocities, and Juliette Gordon Low, founder of the Girl Scouts. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
